content.text: A draft is fundamentally undemocratic and a violation of this nation's principles. Drafting people into the armed services is effectively forcing them into involuntary servitude. It is morally wrong to take away people's personal freedom and put their lives at risk. By relying on a volunteer force, the military has attracted recruits who are committed to serving their country. As the surge in enlistments after the attacks of September 11, 2001, demonstrates, the military has little trouble attracting recruits when Americans are united behind a cause. Reinstating the draft and forcing people into military service would allow the government to pursue unpopular or unnecessary wars. If too few Americans are willing to enlist to fight in a war, then the nation needs to reconsider its overseas commitments.

figure.text:
Opinion 1

Reintroduction of the draft would be good for the military and the nation in general. Service to one's country is a duty of citizenship. The need to reintroduce the draft has become urgent as the military faces a potential crisis in troop strength. Furthermore, the reliance on an all-volunteer force has meant that military service has fallen disproportionately on the sons and daughters of America's poor. Attracted by the economic and educational opportunities the military offers, minorities in particular take on a disproportionate share of the risks of protecting the nation. A draft would create public pressure on our government not to enter into unnecessary conflicts.

A draft is fundamentally undemocratic and a violation of this nation's principles. Drafting people into the armed services is effectively forcing them into involuntary servitude. Reinstating the draft and forcing people into military service would allow the government to pursue unpopular or unnecessary wars. If too few Americans are willing to enlist to fight in a war, then the nation needs to reconsider its overseas commitments.

hotspots.hotspot:
Authoritarian Left

The state is more important than the individual.

State-imposed collectivism

State-imposed collectivism, such as the former Soviet Union, has an entirely state-planned economy and communism.

Voluntary regional collectivism

Land and other means of production are owned by groups at the regional level.

Libertarian left

People believe in the value of each individual.

Libertarian right

People are antigovernment for fiscal or economic reasons rather than for social reasons.

Age

As people get older, they tend to become more conservative.

Gender

Overall, women tend to be more politically liberal, whereas men are more conservative.

Racial Background

Asians tend to identify themselves as more conservative. African Americans and Hispanics have traditionally been more liberal than white Americans, but recent elections indicate that economic levels are more indicative of political leanings than race.

Ethnic Background

Ethnic background can sometimes influence political viewpoints. For example, Cuban Americans tend to lean toward conservative views and politics.

Socioeconomic Group

Wealthier Americans traditionally lean toward more conservative views, while those with lower incomes tend to be more liberal.

Religious Group

Religion tends to have a large impact on views about social issues. Fundamentalist and evangelical Christians are more conservative and hold more traditional beliefs on most issues. Jewish Americans tend to be more liberal.

Family

Early in life, children's views tend to reflect those of their parents. As children mature, however, their views may change based on other factors.

Region

Where one lives seems to affect political attitudes. In the South, more people are conservative, while more people are liberal on the West and East Coasts. Residents of big cities also tend to be more liberal.

Peers

People, especially voters, frequently reflect the views of the peers with whom they associate. It is unknown whether this occurs because they already shared similar views and thus became friends, or if the friendship impacted their views.

content.text: "I was born in a little town called Hope, Arkansas, three months after my father died. I remember that old two-story house where I lived with my grandparents. They had very limited incomes. It was in 1963 that I went to Washington and met President Kennedy at the Boy's Nation program. And I remember just thinking what an incredible country this was, that somebody like me, you know, who had no money or anything, would be given the opportunity to meet the president. That's when I decided I could really do public service because I cared so much about people. I worked my way through law school with part time jobs, anything I could find. After I graduated I really didn't care about making a lot of money. I just wanted to go home and see if I could make a difference. We've worked hard in education and health care to create jobs and we've made real progress. Now it's exhilarating to me to think that as president I could help to change all our people's lives for the better and bring hope back to the American dream."
